description: From Middle English handles, from Old English *handlēas, from Proto-Germanic *handulausaz (“handless”), equivalent to hand +‎ -less. Cognate with West Frisian hânleas (“handless”), German handlos (“handless”), Icelandic handlauss (“handless”).

adjectives.description: handless (comparative more handless, superlative most handless)

examples: This, however, was a thing that, left to himself, would have simply rendered Bill Lampiere a most handless workman at everything he attempted.

description: From handleless, by haplology, under the influence of etymology 1 above.

examples: One battered, spoutless, handless, japanned-in jug, that did not contain water, for it leaked.
